chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: RapidDataMapper have three types of configurations, two will be covered in this chapter:

listitem.para: Several can exist during runtime, but only one can be the default connection.
These settings can only have one set of values, and they control how to fetch, save, create and store the mappers and descriptors.

chapter.para: The two types above can be regarded as the lower level of configurations, they dictate how the system works; what databases are available and where to store the files.
For the third configuration type, which are the descriptors, see the Descriptors chapter.

section.title: Connection configurations
section.para: The connection configurations are managed by the Db class. They are set by using the Db::setConnectionConfig():
The configuration is an array containing several of these values:

row.entry: The identifier of the database driver, see Database Drivers
The hostname for the database to connect to
The username used when connecting to the database
The password used when connecting to the database
The database name of the database to select
The prefix of the database tables the connection should use, automatically used by the Query Builders
If to use a persistent database connection or not
If to use query caching, they usually also require a few extra options
Which type of cache to use, see Query Caching
Options sent to the cache driver, see Query Caching
The character set to use when communicating with the database
The database collation to use when comparing values in the database
If to redirect write queries to another connection, and which connection in that case (string). Useful for master/slave database server arrays.

section.note: Keep in mind that the configuration options might vary depending on the type of database driver.
section.warning: The dbdriver option must be set, otherwise RapidDataMapper will not know what driver to use and an exception will be thrown.

section.title: Mapper and Descriptor management settings
section.para: Descriptors are the third type of configuration which RapidDataMapper uses. Descriptors are usually not entered into the Db class, instead they are loaded when they are needed.

section.title: How descriptors are loaded
section.para: Descriptors can be found in four ways:

listitem.para: First it checks an internal array containing already loaded descriptors, descriptors can be added to this array using Db::addDescriptor(), see Descriptors for more information.
It checks if there is a registered descriptor loader—a callback which will return a valid descriptor. See Alternatives to the Db_Descriptor for more information.
Then it checks if a class with the name of "classDescriptor" exists.
Finally it tries to load a file with the name "class.php" from the directory set by Db::setDescriptorDirectory().

section.para: If all the attempts above fails when loading a descriptor, a Db_DescriptorException exception is thrown.
See Descriptors: Associating descriptors with the class to be mapped for examples and typical usage information.

section.title: Controlling the caching of the mappers
section.para: The mappers are generated and hence they can be cached from one execution to the next to avoid having to recreate them every time (actually, regeneration of mappers in a normal production environment should never happen or be needed).

The mappers are stored in a folder defined by Db::setMapperCacheDir() and it must be writeable by the PHP process running RapidDataMapper (write access can then be revoked once RapidDataMapper has generated the final (production) mappers, provided they shouldn't be changed).
To activate caching of the mappers, first set a folder to store the mappers in with Db::setMapperCacheDir():
If the folder is not writeable—and no cached mapper is found—RapidDataMapper will use eval() to evaluate the generated code instead of using the cache directory.
To start caching, call Db::setCompileMappers() with true as the first parameter:

If $value is set to true, then the mapper management method will try to save generated mappers in the mapper caching directory. If that fails, it will use eval() to still be able to use the mapper(s).
If $value is set to false, then the mapper management method will eval() the generated code right away, not even attempting to check for a cached mapper.
Setting Db::setCompileMappers to false is a good thing to do while developing, as the descriptors—and therefore also the mappers—might change during development.
